comment.author: 77155450@N04
comment._content:
Geoffrey Walter Ingleby (or Ingilby) BAIRSTOW, Lieutenant, 20th Hussars
Born 1891 West Riding Yorkshire
Died 18 July 1941

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content:
No Barstows in 20th Hussars in MICs.
Details as AuneJK has them: Geoffrey Walter Ingilby Bairstow. 
MIC shows BEF 1914. Half pay 3-16. Applied for 1914 Star 27.11.17.
3 addresses shown: "Corners", Camberley; Glebe Farm, Greens Norton, Northants. and The Little House, Wargrave, Berks.

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content:
He was born in 1891 in North Stainley, North Yorkshire and was the son of Walter and Marion Bairstow. In 1901 the family was living in the Warwickshire parish of Lillington St Mary at Kenilworth House. Walter was described as "Living on own means", aged 43 and born at Sutton-in-Craven. His wife was 41 and born in Bingley and their only other child at home, Marjorie, aged 13, had been born in Wharfedale. The family employed 8 live-in servants including a Governess.

GWI Bairstow died on the 18th of July 1941 at Cranford, Victoria Drive, Bognor Regis. Probate was granted to Winifred Florence Brydges Bairstow, widow.

He had married Winifred Florence Brydges Symonds (1889-1980) in 1915 in Bucklow, Cheshire.

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: A printed ancestry shows that Walter Bairstow was JP and High Sheriff of Northamptonshire in 1908. He had married Marion, daughter of Alfred Sharp of Bingley 13 Sep 1882. Geoffrey was their eldest child, born 1 Aug 1891, Cyril Thomas Alfred born 2 July 1903, plus two daughters Agnes Irene  and Marjorie Victoria.

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content:
A 27th October 1925 passenger manifest shows that GWI and his family intended to make thier home in Italy. They were aboard the Nederland Royal Mail Line "Prins Der Nederlanden" heading for Genoa. Country of Intended Future Permanent Residence shown as Italy. Their last address in the UK was The Lodge, Towcester, Northamptonshire. 

No occupation given for GWI, then aged 34. He and his wife had two daughters: Bettina Ingilby-Bairstow aged 9 and Rachel Mary Ingilby-Bairstow aged 4. Also travelling with the family was 20yr old Miss Dorothy Georgina Glover.

The family returned from Italy and, after GWI's death, made their home in the Chichester area. Bettina married there in 1944 and Rachel in 1946.

comment.author: 77155450@N04
comment._content:
St Lawrence Church, Towcester - Brasses
Inscription to Geoffrey W. I. Bairstow (1920)

Brass plaque on organ screen. 
Size 17.5cm x 9cm

TO THE GLORY OF GOD
THESE SCREENS WERE ERECTED BY MR & MRS WALTER BAIRSTOW AND FAMILY AS A THANKS OFFERING TO ALMIGHTLY GOD FOR THE LIFE OF GEOFFREY W.I. BAIRSTOW 20TH HUSSARS BEING SPARED AFTER HE WAS SERIOUSLY WOUNDED IN THE RETREAT FROM MONS.SEPTEMBER 1914. DEDICATED ASCENSION DAY 1920

comment.author: 77155450@N04
comment._content:
From London Gazette 3rd February 1911

The undermentioned Gentlemen Cadets from The Royal Military College to be Second Lieutenants. Dated 4th February 1911.

...

20th Hussars, Geoffrey Walter Ingilby Bairstow.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Geoffrey Walter Ingilby Bairstow comes from a family related to royalty. See The Plantagenet Roll of the Blood Royal: The Mortimer-Percy, p. 560. Ancestors recorded back to Columbus Ingleby 1642-1716 www.mundia.com/ca/Tree/Pedigree/12160593/-323225556#
